Description.val:
The FY 2019 funding request was reduced by $0.048 million to reflect the Department of Navy's effort to support the Office of Management and Budget directed reforms for Efficiency and Effectiveness that include a lean, accountable, more efficient government.

CHEMICAL & BIOLOGICAL DEFENSE PROGRAM (INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS):
Public Law 103-160, Section 1703 created a Joint Service Chemical and Biological Defense Program (CBDP) to address ever growing threats from the aggressive proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. Joint CBDP funds the development and procurement of Chemical and Biological Defense (CBD) Equipment to enhance the warfighter's ability to survive and complete their mission in a chemical biological contaminated environment. The Navy is responsible for the associated installation/integration and sustainment funds only. The Navy's requirement for Joint Biological Point Detection System (JBPDS), Improved Point Detection System/Lifecycle Replacement (IPDS/LR), Joint Biological Agent Identification and Diagnostic System (JBAIDS), Next Generation Chemical Detection (NGDS) System, and Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) system has been validated by CNO in associated Joint Operational Requirements Documents.

Installation of Equipment
Funding is for installation of equipment including Fleet Modernization Program installations, installation of training equipment and installation of equipment in other shore facilities. Procurement of equipment is funded by the Joint
Service CBDP.

Detector installation costs can vary significantly, even within ship class,  depending  on installation location (East coast, West coast, OCONUS, etc.), if installation accomplished pier side or in a ship yard (i.e. availability type during which installation actually occurs), ship as built and as found conditions,  and installation growth work (i.e. unplanned/unexpected work) driven by as found conditions.

[P3A / IPDS/LR]: The IPDS/LR (formerly SEACADS/IPDS) will improve the existing shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying chemical nerve and blister agent contamination presence. Inventory objective for shipboard installations is 125.

[P3A - 2 / JBAIDS]: The JBAIDS will provide U.S. operating forces with a biological organism identification and diagnostic device that will identify and quantify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. Inventory objective for shipboard JBAIDS installations is 23 and Refrigeration installations is 17.

[P3A - 3 / JBAIDS REFRIGERATION UPGRADE]: The JBAIDS systems will detect and identify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. The inventory objective for shipboard installation is 17.

[P3A - 4 / JBPDS BLK 1]: The JBPDS Block I will provide the Navy with automated, knowledge-based capability to detect and identify biological warfare agents in less than 20 minutes. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 76.

[P3A - 5 / NGCD]: The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) is a technology replacement for the IPDS and IPDS-LR systems. The program consists of four variants for multiple applications; the Navy will be installating variant 1 for fixed chemical agent detection capability. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 185.

[P3A - 6 / EMBD]: The Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) is a new acquisition program, which will provide lifecycle replacement kits for existing JBPDS system installations. The EMBD kit is intended to install within the existing JBPDS frame, reducing overall installation complexity and refurbishment unit costs. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 7.

[P3A - 7 / IPDS-LR Heater]: The IPDS-LR Heater Upgrade provides the ability for IPDS-LR to function in various extreme environmental conditions that may cause system degradation and ultimately failure. This is a new, emergent requirement to ensure automated chemical agent detection is operationally available. The equipment development and procurement for this upgrade is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget and is expected to be provided to Navy by early FY 2019. The Navy is required to fund the integration and installation. Inventory objective for shipboard installations is 89.

Name.@footnote: IPDS-LR plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship, excluding IPDS-LR for DDG Class ships which are class-wide drawings.   - FY17 installations total thirteen (13) ships to include one (1) DDG-51 Class funded by FY16 OPN, three (3) MCM Class ship at $180.3K each, three (3) LHD-1 Class ship at $196.7K each, one (1) LPD-17 Class ship at $158K, two (2) LSD-49 Class ships at $185K each, one (1) CG-47 Class ships at $206K, one (1) DDG-51 Class ship at $190K, and one (1) CVN-68 Class ship at $182K. Total installation costs for IPDS-LR in FY17 is $2,237K for twelve (12) ships plus $452K for DSA costs.   - FY18 installations total eleven (11) ships to include  three (3) LSD-41 Class ships at $200.8K each, three (3) CG-47 Class ships at $202.7K each, four (4) DDG-51 Class ships at $187.8K each, and one (1) LCS-2 Class ship at $249.4K. Total installation cost for IPDS-LR in FY18 is $2,211K for eleven (11) ships plus $335K for DSA costs.     - FY19 installations total six (6) ships to include two (2) LSD-49 Class ships at $200K each, two (2) CG-47 Class ships at $194.5K each, one (1) LCS-2 Class ship at $249K, and one (1) HN-1 Class (Aegis Ashore) at $203K.   Total installation costs for FY19 is $1,241K plus $325K for DSA costs.  - FY20 installations total four (4) ships to include one (1) LDS-49 Class at $198K, two (2) CG-47 Class ships at $203.5K each, and one (1) HN-1 Class (Aegis Ashore) at $200K.  Total installation costs for IPDS-LR in FY20 is $805K.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. CBRD IPDS/LR will improve the existing shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying chemical nerve and blister agent contamination presence.  The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget.

[IPDS/LR] Remarks: A total of one hundred and three (103) completed. Planned installations have increased from 123 at PB18 submission to 125 due to the addition of two (2) planned installations at the Aegis Ashore facilities in Romania and Poland.  Recently, it was determined these facilities would be treated as Fleet assets and these two Aegis Ashore sites have automated chemical detection requirements.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.  - FY17 installations include one (1) LHA-6 Class ship at $89.1K (FY16 funded). - FY20 installations include one (1) LHA-6 Class ship at $90K.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBAIDS systems will identify and quantify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. The CENTCOM HR urgent need (dated Aug 2009) modifies the JBAIDS ORD (dated May 2003) with the addition of detection capability for the 2009/A/H1N1 influenza. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: JBAIDS. Beginning in FY13, system will install with refrigeration unit.

[JBAIDS] Remarks: A total of twenty two (22) completed of twenty three (23) planned. The LHA-6 installation started third quarter FY17 and completed July 2017 (Q4). The LHA 7 installation will occur during PSA in FY20. LHA 8 has successfully added JBAIDS to the baseline and should have the system installed during construction.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy  Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBAIDS systems will detect and identify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. The CENTCOM HR urgent need (dated Aug 2009) modifies the JBAIDS ORD (dated May 2003) with the addition of detection capability for the 2009/A/H1N1 influenza. This requires the installation of added support equipment, hard-wired freezers. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: JBAIDS.

[JBAIDS REFRIGERATION UPGRADE] Remarks: A total of seventeen (17) completed of seventeen (17) planned, completing all JBAIDS refrigeration upgrades.

ModificationTitle.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM JBPDS BLK 1

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM JBPDS BLK 1

Name.@footnote: The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship. The LCS 4 and LCS 2 installs are expected to be more expensive than other JBPDS installs because both have partially installed systems that will need to be ripped out and relocated.  - FY17 DSA costs are $100K. - FY18 installations include one (1) LCS-2 Class ship at $400K plus $40K for DSA costs. - FY19 installations include one (1) LCS-2 Class ship at $400K.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10F articulates U.S. Navy CBRD policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of Fleet Readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBPDS BLK I provides for improved biological agent detection and reporting. The JBPDS ORD (J2-B001-Revision 1, dated 7 January, 2002) validates the modification. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: (JP0100) JBPDS

[JBPDS BLK 1] Remarks: A total of 74 completed. Planned quantities increased from 74 to 76 since PB18. Prior submissions had the LCS 2 and LCS 4 listed as EMBD installs starting in FY19, but the Joint developed EMBD program has slipped to FY21 for fielding. To lower Warfighter risk in the interim, LCS-2 & 4 was added back to planned JBPDS installations. Both hulls had JBPDS partially installed by the ship builder during construction, but the system is inoperable. The LCS 2 & 4 JBPDS require removal and relocation to function properly. Systems are planned for removal and relocation in FY18 and FY19 to make functional and complete all planned installations.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10F articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) provides shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying nerve and blister agent contamination presence. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[NGCD] Remarks: The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) is a technology replacement for the IPDS and IPDS-LR systems. The program consists of four variants for multiple applications; the Navy will be installating variant 1 for fixed chemical agent detection capability. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 185. Previously, installations were expected to start in FY21 with advance planning activities (DSA) to start in FY20, but recent Joint program delays now expect NDCD fielding to Navy to commence FY21, necessitating Navy change planned installations to start FY22.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of Ship Installation Drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10F articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) system is intended as a lifecycle replacement for the JBPDS system, and will include improved detection and identification capabilities. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[EMBD] Remarks: EMBD is a new acquisition program, which will provide lifecycle replacement kits for existing JBPDS system installations. The EMBD kit is intended to install within the existing JBPDS frame, reducing overall installation complexity and refurbishment unit costs. Refurbishment of ships already equipped with the JBPDS system will be funded by the Joint Service Chemical Biological Program. However, there are seven (7) ships, previously nine (9), that were planned to receive JBPDS, but will not prior to EMBD entering the fleet. Therefore these seven (7) ships will receive "full" EMBD kits, consisting of both the EMBD refurbishment kit and the overall EMBD/JBPDS shell. LCS-2 and LCS-4 were previously included in the EMBD count, but delays in EMBD development by the Joint program neccesitate removal and installation of JBPDS on these hulls to mitigate Warfighter risk. Installation of these full EMBD systems was projected to begin in FY19, however the schedule has slipped to an FY21 fielding. DSA costs will start to be incurred in FY20 for installation planning and drawing development.

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM IPDS-LR HEATER UPGRADE

Name.@footnote: IPDS-LR Heater Upgrade plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.  - FY18 DSA costs are $50K.    - FY19 installations include twenty (20) DDG-51 Class ships at $30K each plus $400K for DSA costs.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy CBRD policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. CBRD Improved Point Detection System Heater Upgrade (IPDS-LR HU) provides the ability for IPDS-LR to function in various extreme environmental conditions that may cause system degradation and ultimately failure. This is a new, emergent requirement to  ensure automated chemical agent detection is operationally available. The equipment development and procurement for this upgrade is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget and is expected to be provided to Navy by early FY19. Navy must fund integration and installation. DSA costs are expected to start in FY18 with installations to start in FY19.

[IPDS-LR Heater] Remarks: Approximately 115 upgrades are needed of the 125 IPDS-LR installs. Ten (10) ships in FY 2019 and FY 2020 should get this upgrade with the planned IPDS-LR install. Current funding allows for an estimated 89 heater upgrades. The other ships will receive this capability when NGCD replaces IPDS-LR. Once heater upgrade is fully developed by the Joint Service CBDP, further refinement of integration and installation costs can be accomplished. Heater upgrade is currently in prototyping and testing stage.
